Farmers shall count their Leases from this day, Gentlemen their Mortgages from this day: Saint Dennis shall be raced out of the Calendar, and the day of our Instalment entered in red letters: And as Saint Valentine day is fortunate to choose Lovers, SaintLukes to choose Husbands; So shall this day be to the choosing of Lords: It shall be a Critical day, a day of Note: In that day it shall be good to quarrel, but not to fight: They that Marry on that day, shall not repent; marry the morrow after perhaps they may: It shall be wholesome to beat a Sergeant on that day: He that eats Garlic on that morning,shall be a rank Knave till night.

sp.speaker: Diq.
sp.l: What a day will this be, if it hold?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Hold? 'sfoot it shall hold, and shall be held sacred to immortality: let all the Chroniclers, Ballet makers, and Almanac-mungers, do what they dare.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: 'sfoot (my Lord) all is dashed, your voyage is overthrown.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: What ails the frantic Tro?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: The Lady is entombed, that was the Subject of your Embassage: and your Embassage is bewrayed.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Dido is dead,and wrapped in lead.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: O heavy hearse!

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: Your Lordships honour must wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: O scurvy verse! Your Lordship is welcome home: pray let us walk your horse my Lord.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: A pretty gullery. Why my little wits, do you believe this to be true?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: For my part my Lord, I am of opinion you are gulled.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: And I am of opinion that I am partly guilty of the same.

sp.speaker: Muge.
sp.p: Where is this Lord fool here? 'slight you have made a pretty piece of service of it : raised up all the country in gold lace and feathers; and now with your long stay, there is no employment for them.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: Good still.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'slight I ever took thee to be a hammer of the right feather: but I durst have laid my life, no man could ever have crammed such a Gudgeon as this down the throat of thee: To create thee a Christmas Lord, and make thee laughter for the whole Court: I am ashamed of myself that ever I choosed such a Grosseblocke to whet my wits on.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: Good wit i'faith.
sp.p: I know all this is but a gullery now: But since you have presumed to go thus far with me, come what can come to the State, sink or swim, I will be no more a father to it, nor the Duke; nor for the world wade one half steppe further in the action.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: But now your Lordship is gone, what shall become of your followers?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: Followers? let them follow the Court as I have done: there let them raise their fortunes: if not,they know the way to the petty Brokers, there let them shift and hang.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Here we may strike the Plaudit to our Play, my Lord fool is gone: all our audience will forsake us.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Page, after, and call him again.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Let him go: I will take up some other fool for the Duke to employ: every Ordinary affords fools enough: and didst not see a pair of Gallants sit not far hence like a couple of Boughpots to make the room smell?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Yes, they are gone: But what of them?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I will press them to the Court: or if need be, our Muse is not so barren, but she is able to devise one trick or other to retire D'oliue to Court again.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Indeed thou toldest me how gloriously he apprehended the favour of a great Lady in the Presence, whose heart (he said) stood a tiptoe in her eye to look at him.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: It is well remembered.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: O, a Love-letter from that Lady would retrieve him as sure as death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: It would of mine honour: We will fain one from her instantly: Page,fetch pen and ink here.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Now do you and; your Muse engender: my barren sconce shall prompt something.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Soft then: The Lady Ieronime, who I said viewed him so in the Presence, is the Venus that must enamour him: We will go no further for that. But in what likeness must he come to the Court to her now? As a Lord he may not: in any other shape he will not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Then let him come in his own shape like a gull.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Well, disguised he shall be: That shall be his mistress's direction: this shall be my Helicon: and from this quiver will I draw the shaft that shall wound him.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Come on: how wilt thou begin?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Faith thus: Dearly Beloved.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Ware ho, that is profane.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Go to then: Divine D'oliue: I am sure that is not profane.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Well, forward.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I see in the power of thy beauties.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Break off your period, and say, It was with a sigh.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Content: here is a full prick stands for a tear too.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: So, now take my brain.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Pour it on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: I talk like a fool, but alas thou art wise and silent.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Excellent: And the more wise, the more silent.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: That is something common.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: So should his mistress be.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: That is true indeed: Who breaks way next?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: That will I sir: But alas, why art not thou noble, that thou mightst match me in Blood?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: I will answer that for her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: But thou art noble, though not by birth,yet by creation.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: that is not amiss: forth now: Thy wit proves thee to be a Lord, thy presence shows it: O that word Presence, has cost me dear.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Well said, because she saw him in the Presence.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O do but say thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Soft, there is too many OOs.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Not a whit: O is but the next door to P. And his mistress may use her O with with modesty: or if thou wilt,I will stop it with another brackish tear.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: No,no,let it run on.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O do but say thou lovest me, and yet do not neither, and yet do.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Well said, let that last stand, let him do in any case: now say thus, do not appear at Court.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: At least in my company.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: At least before folks.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: For the flame will break forth.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Go on: thou dost well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Where there is fire in the hearth:

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: There will be smoke in the chimney.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Forth.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Warm, but burn me not: there is reason in all things.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Well said, now do I vie it: Come to my chamber betwixt two and three.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: A very good number.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But walk not under my window: if thou dost ,come disguised: in any case wear not thy tuft taffeta cloak: if thou dost, thou killest me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Well said, now to the L'envoye

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thine, if I were worth aught; and yet such, as it skills not whose I am if I be thine; Ieronime: Now for a fit Pander to transport it, and have at him.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Come my good Lord, now will I try my Brain,
If it can forge another golden chain,
To draw the poor Recluse, my honoured mistress
From her dark Cell, and superstitious vow.
I oft have heard there is a kind of cure
To fright a lingering Fever from a man
By an imaginous fear, which may be true,
For one heat (all know) doth drive out another,
One passion doth expel another still,
And therefore I will use a feigned device
To kindle fury in her frozen Breast,
That rage may fire out grief, and so restore her
To her most sociable self again .
And ease my labouring house of such a care.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Mark but my Midwifery: the day is now
Some three hours old, and now her night begins:
Stand close my Lord, if she and her sad meinie
Be toward sleep, or sleeping, I will wake them
With orderly alarms; Page? Boy? sister?
All tongue-tied? all asleep? page? sister?

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.l: Alas Vandome, do not disturb their rest
For pity sake, it is young night yet with them.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: My Lord, your only way to deal with women
And Parrots, is to keep them waking still.
Page? who is above? are you all dead here?

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: 'slight is hell broke loose? who is there?

body.stage: He looks out with a light.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Then know this Castle is the house of woe,
Here harbour none but two distressed Ladies
Condemned to darkness,and this is their jail,
And I the Giant set to guard the same:
My name is Dildo.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Sirrah leave your roguery, and hearken to me: what
Page, I say.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Tempt not disasters: take thy life: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.l: An excellent villainy.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Sirrah? I have business of weight to impart to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: If your business be of weight, let it wait till the after noon, for by that time my Lady will be delivered of her first sleep: Be gone, for fear of watery meteors.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Go to sir, leave your villainy, and dispatch this news to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Is your business from yourself, or from some body besides?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: From nobody besides myself .

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Very good: then I will tell her, here is one besides himself has business to her from nobody .

sp.speaker: Vau.
sp.l: A perfect young hempstring.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Peace lest he overhear you.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: You are not the Constable sir, are you?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Will you dispatch sir? you know me well enough, I am Vandome.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: What is the matter? who is there? Brother

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Sister?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: What tempest drives you hither at such an hour?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Why I hope you are not going to bed, I see you are not yet unready: if ever you will deserve my love, let it be now, by calling forth my mistress, I have news for her, that touch her nearly.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What is it good brother?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: The worst of ills: would any tongue but mine had been the messenger.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What is that servant?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: O Mistress come down with all speed possible, and leave that mournful cell of yours, I will show you another place worthy of your mourning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak man, my heart is armed with a mourning habit of such proof, that there is none greater without it, to pierce it.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: If you please to come down, I will impart what I know: if not,I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Why stand you so at gaze sister? go down to him.
Stay bother, she comes to you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: It will take I doubt not, though herself be ice,
There is one with her all fire, and to her spirit
I must apply my counterfeit device:
Stand close my Lord.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.l: I warrant you, proceed.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Come silly mistress, where is your worthy Lord?
I know you know not, but too well I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now heaven grant all be well.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: How can it be?
While you poor Turtle sit and mourn at home,
Mewed in your cage, your mate he flies abroad,
O heavens who would have thought him such a man?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Why what man brother? I believe my speeches will prove true of him.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: To wrong such a beauty, to profane such virtue,
and to prove disloyal.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Disloyal? nay never gild him over with fine terms. Brother,he is a filthy Lord, and ever was, I did ever say so, I never knew any good on the hair, I do but wonder how you made shift to love him, or what you saw in him to entertain but so much as a piece of a good thought on him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good sister forbear.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Tush sister, bid me not forbear: a woman may bear, and bear,and be never the better thought on neither: I would you had never seen the eyes of him, for I know he never loved you in his life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You wrong him sister, I am sure he loved me
As I loved him, and happy I had been
Had I then died, and shunned this hapless life.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Nay let him die, and all such as as he is, he lay a cater-walling not long since: O if it had been the will of heaven, what a dear blessing had the world had in his riddance?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: But had the lecher none to single out
For object of his light lascivious blood,
But my poor cousin that attends the Duchess, Lady Ieronime.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: What, that blabber-lipped blouse?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Nay no blouse, sister, though I must confess
She comes far short of your perfection.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Yes by my troth, if she were your cousin a thousand times, she is but a sallow freckled face piece when she is at the best.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Yet spare my cousin, sister, for my sake,
She merits milder censure at your hands,
And ever held your worth in noblest terms.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Faith the Gentlewoman is a sweet Gentlewoman of herself , I must needs give her her due.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: But for my Lord your husband, honoured mistress,
He made your beauties and your vertues too,
But foils to grace my cousins, had you seen
His amorous letters,
But my cousin presently will tell you all, for she rejects his suit, yet I advised her to make a show she did not. But point to meet him when you might surprise him, and this is just the hour .

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Gods my life sister, lose not this advantage, it will be a good Trump to lay in his way upon any quarrel: Come,you shall go: 'sbody will you suffer him to disgrace you in this sort? dispraise your beauty? And I do not think too, but he has been as bold with your Honour, which above all earthly things should be dearest to a woman.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Next to her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: True, next to her beauty: and I do not think sister, but he deviseth slanders against you, even in that high kind.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Infinite, infinite.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: And I believe I take part with her too: would I knew that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Make your account, your share is as deep as hers: when you see my cousin,she will tell you all: we will to her presently.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Has she told you, she would tell us?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Assured me, on her oath.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: 'slight I would but know what he can say: I pray you brother tell me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: To what end?it will but stir your patience.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: No I protest: when I know my carriage to be such, as no stain can obscure, his slanders shall never move me, yet would I fain know what he feigns.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.l: It fits not me to play the gossips part: we will to my cousin, she will relate all.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: 'slight what can she say? pray let us have a taste of it onward.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: What can he not say, who being drunk with lust, and surfeiting with desire of change, regards not what he says: and briefly I will tell you thus much now; Let my melancholy Lady (says he) hold on this course till she waste herself , and consume my revenue in Tapers, yet this is certain, that as long as she has that sister of hers at her elbow.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Me? why me? I bid defiance to his foul throat.

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.l: Hold there Vandome, now it begins to take.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: What can his yellow jealousy surmise against me? if you love me, let me hear it: I protest it shall not move me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Marry forsooth, you are the shooing horn, he says , to draw on, to draw on sister.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: The shooing horn with a vengeance? what is his meaning in that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Nay I have done, my cousin shall tell the rest: come shall we go?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Go? by heaven you bid me to a banquet: sister,resolve yourself , for you shall go; lose no more time, for you shall abroad on my life: his licorice chaps are walking by this time: but for heavens sweet hope what means he by that shooing horn? As I live it shall not move me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Tell me but this, did you ever break betwixt my mistress and your sister here, and a certain Lord in the Court?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: How? break?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Go to, you understand me: have not you a Petrarch in Italian?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Petrarch? yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well, he says you can your good, you may be waiting woman to any dame in Europe: that Petrarch does good offices.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Marry hang him, good offices? 'sfoot how understands he that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: As when any Lady is in private courtship with this or that gallant, your Petrarch helps to entertain time: you understand his meaning?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Sister if you resolve to go, so it is: for by heaven your stay shall be no bar to me, I will go, that is infallible: it had been as good he had slandered the devil: shooing horn? O that I were a man for his sake.

sp.speaker: Vand
sp.l: But to abuse your person and your beauty too: a grace wherein this part of the world is happy: but I shall offend too much.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Not me, it shall never move me.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: But to say, ye had a dull eye, a sharpe nose (the visible marks of a shrew) a dry hand, which is a sign of a bad liver, as he said you were, being toward a husband too: this was intolerable.

sp.speaker: Uaum.
sp.l: This strikes it up to the head.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Indeed he said you dressed your head in a pretty strange
fashion: but you would dress your husbands head in a far stranger; meaning the Count of saint Anne I think.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Gods precious, did he touch mine honour with him?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Faith nothing but that he wears black, and says it is his mistress colours: and yet he protests that in his eye your face shows well enough by candle light, for the Count never saw it otherwise, unless it were under a mask, which indeed he says becomes you above all things.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Come Page, go along with me, I will stay for nobody :
It is at your cousins chamber, is it not?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Marry is it, there you shall find him at it.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: That is enough: let my sister go waste his revenue in tapers, it will be her own another day.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good sister, servant, if ever there were any love or respect to me in you both.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Sister? there is no love, nor respect, nor any conjuration, shall stay me: and yet by my part in heaven, I will not be moved a whit with him: you may retire your yourself to your old cell, and there waste your eyes in tears, your heart in sighs, I will away certain.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.l: But soft, let us agree first what course we shall take when we take him.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Marry even raise the streets on him, and bring him forth with a flock of boys about him, to hoot at him.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: No,that were too great a dishonour: I will put him out on his pain presently.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Nay good sir spare his life, cut off the offending part, and save the Count.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is there no remedy? must I break my vow?
Stay I will abroad, though with another aim
Not to procure, but to prevent his shame.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.l: Go Page, march on, you know my cousins chamber,
My company may wrong you, I will cross
The nearer way, and set the house afore you:
But sister see you be not moved for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Not I by heaven: Come sister, be not moved,
But if you spare him, may heaven never spare you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: So now the solemn votary is revived.

sp.speaker: Uaum.
sp.l: Pray heaven you have not gone a step too far,
And raised more sprites, than you can conjure down.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: No my Lord,no, the Herculean Labour is past,
The vow is broke, which was the end we sweat for,
The reconcilement will meet of itself:
Come let us to Court,and watch the Ladies chamber,
Where they are gone with hopeful spleen to see you.

body.stage: Enter Roderique,Mugeron,D'oliue in disguise towards the Ladies chamber.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: See Mugeron, our counterfeit letter hath taken: who is yonder thinkest?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: It is not Doliue.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: If it be not he, I am sure he is not far off:
Those be his trestles that support the motion.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: It is he by heaven, wrapped in his careless cloak:
See the Duke enters: Let him enjoy the benefit of the enchanted Ring, and stand a while invisible: at our best opportunity we will discover him to the Duke.

body.stage: Enter Duke, Dutchesse, Saint Anne, Vaumont, Uandome,to them Digue, whispering Vandome in the eare, and speakes as on the other side.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Monsieur Vandome, yonder is no Lord to be found: my Lady stays at hand and craves your speech.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Tell her she mistook the place, and conduct her hither: How will she look when she finds her expectation mocked now?

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.l: What is that, Uandome?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Your wife and sister are coming hither, hoping to take you and my cousin together.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.l: Alas, how shall we appease them, when they see themselves so deluded?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Let me alone, and stand you off my Lord:

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Madam, you are welcome to the Court: do you see your Lord yonder? I have made him happy by training you forth: In a word,all I said was but a train to draw you from your vow: Nay,there is no going back: Come forward and keep your temper. Sister, cloud not you your forehead: yonder is a Sun will clear your beauties I am sure. Now you see the shoeing horn is expounded: all was but a shoeing horn to draw you hither: now show yourselves women,and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let him alone awhile Uandome, who is there? what whisper you?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Ye have done? come forward:
See here my Lord, my honourable mistress,
And her fair sister, whom your Highness knows
Could never be importuned from their vows
By prayer, or the earnest suits of any friends,
Now hearing false report that your fair Duchess
Was dangerously sick, to visit her
Did that which no friend else could win her to,
And brake her long kept vow with her repair.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Madam you do me an exceeding honour,
In showing this true kindness to my Duchess,
Which she with all her kindness will requite.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Now my good Lord, the motion you have made,
With such kind importunity by yourself,
And seconded with all persuasions
On my poor part, for marriage of this Lady,
Herself now comes to tell you she embraces,
And (with that promise made me)I present her.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Sister, we must forgive him.

sp.speaker: S.An.
sp.l: Matchless Lady,
Your beauties and your vertues have achieved
An action that I thought impossible,
For all the sweet attractions of your sex,
In your conditions, so to life resembling
The grace and fashion of my other wife:
You have revived her to my loving thoughts,
And all the honours I have done to her,
Shall be continued (with increase) to you.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Now let us discover our Ambassador,my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Do so.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: My Lord? my Lord Ambassador?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: My Lord fool, am I not?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Go to, you are he: you cannot cloak your Lordship from our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Come, come: could Achilles hide himself under a woman's clothes? Greatness will shine through clouds of any disguise.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who is that Rhoderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Monsieur D'oliue, my Lord, stolen hither disguised, with what mind we know not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: Never strive to be gone sir: my Lord, his habit expounds his heart: it were good he were searched.

sp.speaker: D'oliue.
sp.p: Well rooks well, I will be no longer a block to whet your dull wits on: My Lord, my Lord, you wrong not yourself only, but your whole state, to suffer such ulcers as these to gather head in your Court; never look to have any action sort to your honour, when you suffer such earwigs to creep into your ears thus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is the matter Rhoderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, only the lightness of his brain, because his hopes are lost.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.l: For our parts, we have been trusty and secret to him in the whole manage of his embassage.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Trusty? a plague on you both, there is as much trust in a common whore as in one of you: and as for secrecy, there is no more in you Than in a professed Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Why a Scrivener, Monsieur D'oliue?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.l: Marry sir a man cannot trust him with borrowing so much as poor forty shillings, but he will have it Known to all men by these presents.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: That is true indeed, but you employed these gentlemen very safely.

sp.speaker: D'oliue.
sp.p: Employed? Aye marry sir, they were the men that first kindled this humour of employment in me: a pox of employment I say: it has cost me, but what it has cost me, it skills not: they have thrust upon me a crew of threadbare, unbuttoned fellows, to be my followers: Tailors, Frippers, Brokers, cashiered Clerks, Pettifoggers, and I know not who I: 'slight I think they have swept all the bowling allies in the city for them: and a crew of these, raked like old rags out of dunghills by candle light, have they presented to me in very good fashion, to be gentlemen of my train, and sold them hope of raising their fortunes by me: A plague on that phrase, Raising of fortunes, it has undone more men than ten dicing houses: Raise their fortunes with a vengeance? And a man will play the fool and be a Lord,or be a fool and play the Lord, he shall be sure to want no followers, so there be hope to raise their fortunes. A burning fever light on you, and all such followers. 'sfoot they say followers are but shadows, that follow their Lords no longer than the sun shines on them: but I find it not so: the sun is set upon my employment, and yet I cannot shake off my shadows; my followers grow to my heels like kibes, I cannot stir out of doors for them . And your grace have any employment for followers, pray entertain my company: they will spend their blood in your service, for they have little else to spend, you may soon raise their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well Monsieur D'oliue your forwardness
In this intended service, shall well know
What acceptation it hath won itself
In our kind thoughts: nor let this sudden change
Discourage the designments you have laid
For our States good: reserve yourself I pray,
Till fitter times: mean time will I secure you
From all your followers: follow us to Court.
And good my Lords, and you my honoured Ladies,
Be all made happy in the worthy knowledge
Of this our worthy friend Monsieur D'oliue

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good Monsieur D'oliue.
